steps Package¶

abc_step Module¶

Created on Jul 30, 2012

@author: Gary

class housemonitor.steps.abc_step.abcStep[source]¶

Bases: lib.base.Base

This is a abstract class which is used by the step routines to convert one type of data to another.

For example: To convert Centigrade to Fahrenheit:

  1. Create a class that has a base class of abcStep.

  2. Add a function called step that does the conversion.

  3. Add the other abstract methods and properties that are required:
    1. topic_name The topic name to which this routine subscribes.
    2. logger_name Set the logger name.

For an example see the other files in the step directory.

counter = 0¶

Contains the number of times that step has been called

errors = 0¶

Contains the number of errors.

getErrorCount(value, data, listeners)[source]¶

Report the number of errors that has occurred in this step.

Parameters:
  • value (int) – Not used.
  • data –
    a dictionary containing more information about the
    value. Data can be added to this as needed. Here is a list of values that will be in the data dictionary:
    1. date: time received: time when value was received.
    2. units: units of the number
    3. name: name assigned to the value
  • listeners – a list of the subscribed routines to send the data to
Returns:

count, data, listeners
Return type:

float, dict, listeners
Raises :

None

 
>>> from steps.zigbee2volts import ZigbeeCountToVolts
>>> zig = ZigbeeCountToVolts()
>>> zig.getErrorCount(100, {'device': 'xyz', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])
getUseCount(value, data, listeners)[source]¶

Report the number of times that step has been called.

Parameters:
  • value (int) – Not used.
  • data – a dictionary containing more information about the value.
  • listeners – a list of the subscribed routines to send the to.
Returns:

int, dict, listeners

 
>>> from steps.zigbee2volts import ZigbeeCountToVolts
>>> zig = ZigbeeCountToVolts()
>>> zig.getUseCount(100, {'device': 'xyz', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])
(0, {'device': 'xyz', 'units': 'V', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])
>>> zig.step(1, {'device': 'xyz', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])
>>> zig.getUseCount(100, {'device': 'xyz', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])
(1, {'device': 'xyz', 'units': 'V', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])

step(value, data, listeners)[source]¶

Abstract method for the procedure that does all user specific computations.

Parameters:
  • value (int, float, string, etc) – The input value to be processesed
  • data –
    a dictionary containing more information about the
    value. Data can be added to this as needed. Here is a list of values that will be in the data dictionary:
    1. date: time received: time when value was received.
    2. units: units of the number
    3. name: name assigned to the value
    4. device name of the device the data is from.
    5. port name of the port the data is from.
  • listeners – a list of the subscribed routines to send the data to
Returns:

new_value, new_data, new_listeners
Return type:

int, dict, listeners
Raises :

None
substep(value, data, listeners)[source]¶

This function is wraps step function. It counts usage, errors then sends the data to next function.

Parameters:
  • value (int, float, string, etc) – The number to convert to volts.
  • data –
    a dictionary containing more information about the
    value. Data can be added to this as needed. Here is a list of values that will be in the data dictionary:
    1 date: time received: time when value was received.
    2. units: units of the number
    3. name: name assigned to the value
    4. device name of the device the data is from.
    5. port name of the port the data is from.
  • listeners – a list of the pubsub routines to send the data to
Returns:

value, data, listeners
Return type:

value, dict, listeners
Raises :

None

average Module¶

Created on 2012-10-17

@author: Gary

class housemonitor.steps.average.Average[source]¶

Bases: steps.abc_step.abcStep

This class will take the average of the last N samples.

Where N is the DEFAULT_SAMPLES(10) or the sample size that is defined in the file ‘avg.xml’.

The format of avg.xml is as follows:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<average>
    <item device="0x13a200409029bf" port="adc-1">30</item>
</average>

The proceding file will cause samples from device 0x13a200409029bf port adc-1 to be average over 30 samples.

DEFAULT_SAMPLES = 10¶

The default number of samples to average.

configuration_file_name[source]¶

The topic name to which this routine subscribes.

get_number_of_samples(device, port)[source]¶

get the number of samples for this port and device.

The number of samples is stored it the xml configuration file

Parameters:
  • device (string) – The name of the device.
  • port (string) – The name of the port.
Returns:

The number of samples for this device and port. If the file does not contain the number the use the default.
get_samples(device, port, number_of_samples)[source]¶

get the samples from the samples dict. If one has not been defined then create a deque for data samples.

Parameters:
  • device (string) – The name of the device.
  • port (string) – The name of the port.
  • number_of_samples – The number of samples for generating the averaage.
  • samples –
    • the deque for storing the data samples. Its maxlen will be set to the number of samples
Returns:

degue for storing the data
logger_name[source]¶

Set the logger name.

samples = {}¶

The repository cantaining the samples for each device.

save_samples(device, port, samples)[source]¶

save the samples in the data structure self.samples

Parameters:
  • device (string) – The name of the device.
  • port (string) – The name of the port.
  • samples (dequeue) – a deque containing the data that will saved to generate the average
Raises :

None
step(value, data={}, listeners=[])[source]¶

This function will compute the average for each device and port.

Parameters:
  • value (int or float) – The number to add to the list of numbers.
  • data –
    a dictionary containing more information about the
    value. Data can be added to this as needed. Here is a list of values that will be in the data dictionary:
    1. date: time received: time when value was received.
    2. units: units of the number
    3. name: name assigned to the value
  • listeners – a list of the subscribed routines to send the data to
Returns:

average, data, listeners
Return type:

float, dict, listeners
Raises :

ValueError, KeyError

 
>>> from steps.average import Average
>>> avg = Average()
>>> avg.step(0.0, {'device': 'xyz', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])
(0, {'device': 'xyz', 'units': 'V', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])
>>> avg.step(1.0, {'device': 'xyz', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])
(0.5, {'device': 'xyz', 'units': 'V', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])
topic_name[source]¶

The topic name to which this routine subscribes.

centigrade2fahrenheit Module¶

Created on Aug 2, 2012

@author: Gary

class housemonitor.steps.centigrade2fahrenheit.ConvertCentigradeToFahrenheit[source]¶

Bases: housemonitor.steps.abc_step.abcStep

Convert from Centigrade to Fahrenheit

logger_name[source]¶

Set the logger level. This needs to be added to house_monitoring_logging.conf

step(value, data={}, listeners=[])[source]¶

Convert from Centigrade to Fahrenheit

Parameters:
  • value (boolean, int or float) – The number to add to the list of numbers.
  • data –

    a dictionary containing more information about the value. Data can be added to this as needed. Here is a list of values that will be in the data dictionary:

    1. date: time received: time when value was received.
    2. units: units of the number
    3. name: name assigned to the value
  • listeners – a list of the subscribed routines to send the data to
Returns:

value, data, listeners
Return type:

value, dict, listeners
Raises :

None

 
>>> from steps.centigrade2fahrenheit import ConvertCentigradeToFahrenheit
>>> c2f = ConvertCentigradeToFahrenheit()
>>> c2f.step(0, {'device': 'xyz', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])
(32.0, {'device': 'xyz', 'units': 'F', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])
>>> c2f.step(100, {'device': 'xyz', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])
(212.0, {'device': 'xyz', 'units': 'F', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])

The topic name to which this routine subscribes.

formatvalue Module¶

Created on Oct 16, 2012

@author: Gary

class housemonitor.steps.formatvalue.FormatValue[source]¶

Bases: housemonitor.steps.abc_step.abcStep

Format values as specified in the format configuration file.

For more on python formatting see the following web page:

Format Specification Mini-Language.

The format of the formatting configuration file is:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<formats>
    <item device="0x13a200409029bf" port="adc-1">{:3.1f}</item>
    <item device="0x13a200408cccc3" port="adc-0">{:3.1f}</item>
    <item device="0x13a200408cccc3" port="adc-1">{:3.1f}</item>
</formats>
configuration_file_name[source]¶

The topic name to which this routine subscribes.

logger_name[source]¶

Set the logger level.

step(value, data={}, listeners=[])[source]¶

This function will format value as specified in the format stored in formatvalue.xml.

Parameters:
  • value (boolean, string, int or float) – The value to format.
  • data –
    a dictionary containing more information about the
    value. Data can be added to this as needed. Here is a list of values that will be in the data dictionary:
    1. date: time received: time when value was received.
    2. units: units of the number
    3. name: name assigned to the value
  • listeners – a list of the subscribed routines to send the data to
Returns:

value, data, listeners
Return type:

float, dict, listeners
Raises :

ValueError, KeyError
topic_name[source]¶

The topic name to which this routine subscribes.

step(value, data={}, listeners=[])[source]¶

  • data – a dictionary containing more information about the value.

oneInN Module¶

Created on 2012-11-14

@author: Gary

class housemonitor.steps.oneInN.OneInN[source]¶

Bases: housemonitor.steps.abc_step.abcStep

This class will pass along one in N samples. This could be used to slow the rate that samples will be sent to some remote site. ie. COSM

The N is stored in an xml file named oneInN.xml. It looks as follows:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<OneInN>
    <item device="0x13a200409029bf" port="adc-1">10</item>
</OneInN>
config = None¶

Configuration data.

configuration_file_name()[source]¶

The topic name to which this routine subscribes.

count = None¶

Montains a count for each input device port combination.

logger_name[source]¶

Set the logger level.

step(value, data={}, listeners=[])[source]¶

This function will take one sample out of limit samples.

Parameters:
  • value (boolean, int or float) – The number to add to the list of numbers.
  • data –
    a dictionary containing more information about the
    value. Data can be added to this as needed. Here is a list of values that will be in the data dictionary:
    1. date: time received: time when value was received.
    2. units: units of the number
    3. name: name assigned to the value
  • listeners – a list of the subscribed routines to send the data to
Returns:

value, data, listeners
Return type:

value, dict, listeners
Raises :

KeyError

 
>>> from steps.oneInN import oneInN
>>> oneInN = oneInN()
>>> c2f.step(0, {'device': 'test', 'port': 'test'}, ['a', 'b'])
(32.0, {'device': 'test', 'units': 'F', 'port': 'test'}, [])
>>> c2f.step(100, {'device': 'test', 'port': 'test'}, ['a', 'b'])
(212.0, {'device': 'test', 'units': 'F', 'port': 'test'}, ['a', 'b'])

statuspanel Module¶

Created on 2012-11-14

@author: Gary

class housemonitor.steps.statuspanel.StatusPanel[source]¶

Bases: lib.base.Base

The Status Panel is responsible for updating the kitchen status panel. The status panel consists for a:

# Green flashing LED that indicates that the system is functioning. # A red LED that glows when the garage door is open. # A alarm that will sound X minutes after the garage door has opened. # A disable button that will disable the alarm.

A schematic is in the Fritzing directory.

ALARM_OFF = True¶
ALARM_ON = False¶
DISABLE_ALARM = False¶
class DisableAlarmButton(status_panel)[source]¶

Bases: housemonitor.steps.abc_step.abcStep

DisableAlarmButton will be waiting for the disable alarm button to be pressed. When it is pressed it will disable the alarm until the garage door is closed.

logger_name[source]¶

Set the logger level.

step(value, data={}, listeners=[])[source]¶
Will detect if the garage door disable button has been pressed. If it has it will:
1. set disable alarm to disabled
2. turn off the alarm
Parameters:
  • value (Boolean) – The state of the garage door
  • data –
    a dictionary containing more information about the
    value. Data can be added to this as needed. Here is a list of values that will be in the data dictionary:
    1. date: time received: time when value was received.
    2. units: units of the number
    3. name: name assigned to the value
    4. etc.
  • listeners – a list of the subscribed routines to send the data to
Returns:

value, data, listeners
Return type:

Boolean, dict, listeners
topic_name[source]¶

The topic name to which this routine subscribes.

StatusPanel.ENABLE_ALARM = True¶
StatusPanel.GARAGE_DOOR_CLOSED = True¶
StatusPanel.GARAGE_DOOR_OPEN = False¶
class StatusPanel.GarageDoorMonitor(status_panel)[source]¶

Bases: housemonitor.steps.abc_step.abcStep

GarageDoorMonitor is a class that receives the message about the garage door.

logger_name[source]¶

Set the logger level.

setTimerToActivateAlarmAfterInterval()[source]¶

This will start a timer when the garage door opens. When the timer expire a message will be sent to StartAlarm.step() which will start the alarm.

step(value, data={}, listeners=[])[source]¶
Will detect if the garage door has been opened. If it has it will:
1. Set the time when the door was opened
2. disable the alarm
3. Turn off the alarm
It will always do the following:
1. Set the garage door to the value that was passed in
2. Start a timer that will send a message in X minutes telling the system
to recheck the garage door and if it is still open start the alarm.
Parameters:
  • value (Boolean) – The state of the garage door
  • data – a dictionary containing more information about the value.
  • listeners – a list of the subscribed routines to send the data to
Returns:

value, data, listeners
Return type:

Boolean, dict, listeners
topic_name[source]¶

The topic name to which this routine subscribes.

class StatusPanel.StartAlarm(status_panel)[source]¶

Bases: housemonitor.steps.abc_step.abcStep

StartAlarm will start the alarm. It will sound until the garage door is closed or the disable ararm button is pressed.

logger_name[source]¶

Set the logger level.

step(value, data={}, listeners=[])[source]¶

This routine will receive a message X minutes after the door has been opened. If the garage door is still open and the alarm has not been disabled, it will start the alarm:

1. set disable alarm to disabled
2. turn off the alarm
Parameters:
  • value (Boolean) – Not used
  • data – a dictionary containing more information about the value.
  • listeners – a list of the subscribed routines to send the data to
Returns:

value, data, listeners
Return type:

Boolean, dict, listeners
topic_name[source]¶

The topic name to which this routine subscribes.

tmp36volts2centigrade Module¶

Created on Jul 30, 2012

@author: Gary

class housemonitor.steps.tmp36volts2centigrade.ConvertTMP36VoltsToCentigrade[source]¶

Bases: housemonitor.steps.abc_step.abcStep

Convert from TMP36 volts to Centigrade

logger_name[source]¶

Set the logger name. This needs to be added to house_monitoring_logging.conf

step(value, data={}, listeners=[])[source]¶

Convert from TMP36 volts to Centigrade The formula can be found at:

http://learn.adafruit.com/tmp36-temperature-sensor

Parameters:
  • value (int, float) – The number to convert from volts to centigrade.
  • data – a dictionary containing more information about the value.
  • listeners – a list of the subscribed routines to send the data to
Returns:

centigrade, data, listeners
Return type:

float, dict, listeners

 
>>> from steps.tmp36volts2centigrade import ConvertTMP36VoltsToCentigrade
>>> zig = ConvertTMP36VoltsToCentigrade()
>>> zig.step(0.8, {'device': 'xyz', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])
(30.0, {'device': 'xyz', 'units': 'C', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])
topic_name[source]¶

The topic name to which this routine subscribes.

zigbee2volts Module¶

Created on Jul 30, 2012

@author: Gary

class housemonitor.steps.zigbee2volts.ZigbeeCountToVolts[source]¶

Bases: housemonitor.steps.abc_step.abcStep

Convert Zigbee count to Volts

VOLTS_PER_COUNT = 0.001171875¶
logger_name[source]¶

Set the logger name. This needs to be added to house_monitoring_logging.conf

step(value, data={}, listeners=[])[source]¶

Convert the Zigbee analog count(value) to volts

Math :V = ( 1.2 * count ) / 1024

The formula can be found at:

See also

http://learn.adafruit.com/tmp36-temperature-sensor

Parameters:
  • value (Boolean) – Not used
  • data – a dictionary containing more information about the value.
  • listeners – a list of the subscribed routines to send the data to
Returns:

value, data, listeners
Return type:

Boolean, dict, listeners

 
>>> from steps.zigbee2volts import ZigbeeCountToVolts
>>> zig = ZigbeeCountToVolts()
>>> zig.step(700, {'device': 'xyz', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])
(0.8203125, {'device': 'xyz', 'units': 'V', 'port': 'abc'}, ['a', 'b'])
topic_name[source]¶

The topic name to which this routine subscribes.

housemonitor.steps.zigbee2volts.instantuate_me(data)[source]¶

This function is used to instantuate this modules class

instantuate_me(data) returns ZigbeeCountToVolts object :param data: a dictionary containing several options needed by some steps: (options and args passed in from the command line) :returns: ZigbeeCountToVolts object
